Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: A journal submission deadline is imminent and requires the finalized report and datasets.
Story: I sat at my desk, laptop open, fingers hovering over the keyboard as the clock ticked closer to midnight. The journal’s submission portal blinked on my screen, reminding me that the finalized report and datasets were due in just a few hours. My mind raced through the data, double-checking every figure, every sentence, knowing that accuracy was everything in my work as a scientist. But from the living room, I could hear my stepfather’s voice, softer than usual, as he spoke to my mother. I remembered how I’d promised myself to check in on them more, to be the step-child who noticed when things weren’t quite right at home. I knew they expected me to ask, to care, to be present. Yet, the weight of my research pressed down on me, demanding my full attention. My heart tugged me toward the living room, but my mind screamed that I couldn’t afford a single distraction. I sat frozen, torn between the family who needed my support and the career that demanded my precision, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me.
